ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: UV-visible and infrared absorption spectra of Bi2O3 in lithium phosphate glasses and effect of gamma irradiation

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Ultraviolet and visible absorption spectra of prepared undoped lithium phosphate glass and samples of the same nominal composition with additional Bi2O3 contents were measured before and after being subjected to gamma doses of 3 and 6 Mrad. The base undoped lithium phosphate glass exhibits strong charge transfer ultraviolet absorption bands, which are related to unavoidable presence of trace iron impurities within the raw materials for the preparation of this glass. Bi2O3-containing glasses show the extension of UV absorption beside the resolution of visible bands at 400, 450, and 700 nm with the increase of Bi2O3 content due the sharing of absorption of Bi3+ ions. Gamma irradiation of the base glass reveals extended induced bands; the UV bands are related to the conversion of some Fe2+ to Fe3+ through photochemical reactions during the irradiation process. The visible induced bands are related to the formation of positive hole centers from the host phosphate glass. Glasses containing Bi2O3 are observed to show some shielding behavior, which is attributed to the presence of heavy weight and large atomic number of Bi3+ ions. Infrared absorption spectral measurements of the base lithium phosphate glass show characteristic vibrational modes which are related to specific phosphate groups. The addition of Bi2O3 in measurable percent produces additional vibrational bands due to the introduction of Bi–O groups such as BiO3 and BiO6.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Glasses containing heavy metal oxides such as Bi2O3 have attracted the attention of several workers for their high refractive index, and hence showing large polarization, high optical basicity, and large third-order nonlinear optical susceptibility [1, 2]. These glasses have potential applications in the field of glass ceramics, layers for optical and electronic devices, thermal and mechanical sensors, reflecting windows, and superconducting materials [3, 4]. Due to the high density and transparency, these glasses are also useful for a variety of optical applications, such as radiation shielding windows and scintillation counters [5–8].

The interactions of nuclear radiation such as gamma rays and neutron beams with transition metals, rare earths or heavy metals containing glasses are very important from a scientific point view. Such interactions cause noticeable changes in the physical and chemical properties of glasses [9–12]. It was found that these changes depend not only on the type of radiation and dose, but also on glass type and composition [10–12]. The resultant radiation defects may be divided into three categories [12]: (1) Atomic displacement by momentum and energy transfer, (2) Ionization and charge trapping, and (3) Radiolysis or photochemical effect. Irradiation of glass usually results in the occurrence of all three processes (or at least in the second and third); the relative contributions to the net damage depend on the type and energy of the radiation, as well as the total dose.

Ultraviolet-visible and infrared absorption spectroscopy are recently employed by the present authors as valuable techniques to obtain information about induced defects, which are generated in glasses through successive gamma irradiation (e.g., [5–7]). Such combined tools could identify by optical measurements the induced radiation color centers in undoped and various transition metal ions-doped glasses from various systems and compositions. On the contrary, IR spectroscopic measurements indicate that most vibrational bands due to network constitutional groups in glasses retain their numbers and positions mostly unaffected by gamma irradiation except minor changes in their intensities or positions, and these minor changes are mostly related to variations in the bond angles and/or bond lengths of the structural groups.

Binary alkali phosphate glasses are accepted to be improved through their chemical and physical properties by the addition of multivalent oxides such as SiO2, Al2O3, B2O3 or heavy metal oxide (e.g., PbO, Bi2O3,…). Addition of Bi2O3 in phosphate glasses lowers the phonon energy and radiation properties are improved [4–7]. Also, the addition of Bi2O3 to phosphate glass leads to improvement in its chemical durability [8].

The aim of the present work is to investigate the optical and IR absorption spectra of some lithium phosphate glasses containing additional Bi2O3 percents and to remeasure the same spectral properties after the samples being subjected to two successive gamma irradiation doses (3, 6 Mrad). This study reports the identification of the induced damages generated in this glass system by gamma irradiation and the reasoning of such induced radiation defects together with identifying the role of Bi2O3 on the two measured spectral properties.

Section2.Heading: Preparation of glasses
Section2.Para:
Chemically pure materials were used to prepare the studied glasses including NH4H2PO4, Li2CO3, and Bi2O3 with chemical compositions as shown in Table 1. The prepared batches were melted in platinum crucibles at 1100±10 °C for 1 hour and the melts were stirred at intervals. The samples containing Bi2O3 were crushed in agate mortar and remelted for another 30 minutes to achieve homogeneity and clear samples. The melts were cast into warmed stainless steel molds of the required dimensions. The prepared samples were immediately transferred to a muffle furnace regulated at 370 °C for annealing. The muffle furnace was switched off after 1 hour and left to cool to room temperature at a rate of 25 °C /hour.

Section2.Heading: UV-visible absorption spectra
Section2.Para: The optical [UV-VIS] absorption spectra before and after successive gamma irradiation were measured at room temperature in the range from 200 to 1000 nm using a computerized recording spectrophotometer {type T80t, PG Instrument Ltd., England}. Highly polished samples of equal thickness [2±0.1 mm] were used in these measurements.

Section2.Heading: Infrared absorption spectra
Section2.Para: FT infrared absorption spectra of the glasses were measured at room temperature in the range 4000–400 cm−1 by an infrared spectrophotometer [type Mattson 5000 FTIR spectrometer] using the KBr disc technique. The samples were pulverized into fine powder, and then the powdered samples were mixed with potassium bromide powder with a weight ratio of 1:100. The mixture was subjected to a load of 5 tons cm−2 in an evocable die for 2 min to produce clear homogenous discs. The IR absorption spectra were measured immediately after preparing the discs.

Section2.Heading: Irradiation facility
Section2.Para: A 60Co gamma cell [2000 Ci] was used as a gamma ray source with a dose rate of 1.5 Gy s−1 {150 rad s−1} at a temperature of 30 °C. The investigated glasses were subjected to the same gamma dose every successive time.

Section2.Heading: UV-visible absorption spectrum of undoped lithium phosphate glass
Section2.Para:
Figure 1 illustrates the UV-visible absorption spectrum of the base lithium phosphate glass before gamma irradiation. The spectrum shows distinct sharp UV absorption with a main peak at about 215 nm with a neighboring secondary peak at 210 nm and no visible band could be identified. On subjecting this glass to a dose of 3 Mrad, the UV absorption becomes broader revealing two peaks at about 235 and 275 nm and a new visible band is identified at about 430 nm. On further irradiation to 6 Mrad, the UV spectrum shows a broader absorption band with three peaks at about 260, 300, 320 and followed by two curvatures at about 340 and 425 nm.
Fig. 1
Absorption spectrum of base lithium phosphate glasses

Section2.Heading: UV-visible absorption spectra of Bi2O3-containing glasses
Section2.Para:
Figures 2, 3, 4 show the optical absorption spectra of lithium phosphate glasses with increasing Bi2O3 contents. With 1 % Bi2O3 glass, the optical spectrum reveals a broad strong UV spectrum extending from 200 to about 280 nm centered at about 250 nm beside a small broad visible band centered at about 450 nm. With the samples containing 2–4 % Bi2O3, the UV spectra are almost the same as the first sample, but the visible band slightly grows in intensity with the increase of Bi2O3 content. With glass containing 5 % Bi2O3, the optical spectrum is observed to be composed of two connected very broad absorption bands extending within the UV and visible regions from 200 to about 700 nm. The UV part of the spectrum consists of strong absorption from 200 to about 340 nm with obvious peaking at 240 and 300 nm and the connected visible spectrum consists of strong and wide absorption with peaks at about 400 and 450 nm and followed by a small broad band centered at about 700 nm.
Fig. 2
Absorption spectra of Bi2O3-containing lithium phosphate glass before gamma irradiation
Fig. 3
Absorption spectra of Bi2O3-containing lithium phosphate glasses after 3MR gamma irradiation
Fig. 4
Absorption spectra of Bi2O3-containing glasses after 6 MR gamma irradiation
With the glass containing 7.5 % Bi2O3, the UV-visible absorption spectrum is observed to be similar to the spectrum as that of the sample with 5 % Bi2O3, but the peak at 400 nm is more intensified.

On subjecting the Bi2O3-containing glasses to the first dose of gamma irradiation (3 Mrad), the glasses containing Bi2O3 up to 5 % show a spectrum consisting of strong UV absorption with two bands at about 235 and 275 nm and followed by a distinct broad visible band centered at 440–470 nm and a small curvature at about 700 nm. When the Bi2O3 content reaches 7.5 %, the optical spectrum after gamma irradiation consists of two intensive connected UV-near visible broad bands with the UV spectrum showing two peaks at about 240 and 290 nm, and the second connected visible band revealing two peaks at about 400 and 470 nm. Also, the optical spectrum shows a curvature at about 695 nm. On further gamma irradiation to a dose of 6 Mrad, the UV-visible spectra are obviously retaining the same spectral characteristics as that observed with the previous dose of 3 Mrad.

Section2.Heading: Induced spectra
Section2.Para:
Figures 5 and 6 reveal the induced spectra of the base and Bi2O3-containing lithium phosphate glasses, which are obtained by subtraction of the optical densities obtained from unirradiated samples from that of the same samples after each specified dose of gamma irradiation. Thus, the given results express the net induced spectral results of the base and Bi2O3-containing samples showing ΔD, which is the difference in optical density against wavelength for each sample. The resultant induced spectra are summarized as follows:
(a)
The undoped lithium phosphate glass Fig. 5 shows a strong and broad induced UV band with maximum at about 275 nm and followed by an induced broad medium visible band centered at about 420 nm. With further irradiation to 6 Mrad, the UV band maximum shifts to longer wavelength reaching 300 nm and the induced visible band increases in intensity and with its peak reaching 400 nm.
Fig. 5
Induced spectra of lithium phosphate glass subjected to gamma ray doses of 3 and 6 Mrad
(b)
Figure 6 illustrates the induced spectra of Bi2O3-containing samples after 3 Mrad dose of irradiation. It is obvious that with the samples containing up to 4 % Bi2O3, the induced spectra reveal a strong induced UV band at 285–300 nm and an extra medium band at about 350 nm. With further increase of the Bi2O3 content and specifically with glasses containing 5 and 7.5 % Bi2O3, the induced spectra show obvious shielding effects toward irradiation and the strong induced UV band is not observed. The induced spectra reveal a small UV band at 275 and an induced broad visible band centered at 430 nm with the highest Bi2O3 content.
Fig. 6
Induced spectra of Bi2O3-containing glasses after 3 MR gamma irradiation
(c)
Figure 7 illustrates the induced spectra of Bi2O3-containing samples after the final dose 6 Mrad of irradiation. It is obvious that the glasses containing 1, 2, and 3 % Bi2O3 reveal a strong induced UV absorption band at about 280 nm followed by an induced broad band centered at about 500 nm. The first UV band progressively decreases in intensity with increasing Bi2O3 content while the second band increases but with lower rate. With higher Bi2O3 contents 4, 5, and 7.5 %, the induced UV band has almost disappeared and the last glass shows an induced broad visible band at about 435 nm.
Fig. 7
Induced spectra of Bi2O3-containing glasses after 6MR gamma irradiation

Section2.Heading: Infrared absorption spectra of base lithium phosphate glass and Bi2O3-containing lithium phosphate glasses
Section2.Para:
Figure 8 illustrates the IR absorption spectra of the base lithium phosphate glass and also that for samples containing successive percents of Bi2O3. The IR spectral characteristics obtained from the base lithium phosphate glass are summarized as follows:
(a)
A medium peak at about 475 cm−1.
(b)
Three subsequent small peaks at about 600, 650, and 710 cm−1.
(c)
A medium peak at about 790 cm−1.
(d)
A small kink at about 850 cm−1.
(e)
A high intense and very broad band with two distinct peaks at about 920 and 1090 cm−1.
(f)
A very strong and broad band at about 1315 cm−1.
(g)
A small peak at about 1640 cm−1 and followed by another small kink at about 1720 cm−1.
(h)
Five small peaks at about 2040, 2300, 2780, 2820, and 2910 cm−1.
(i)
A very broad band centered at about 3440 cm−1 and with a connected small kink at about 3200 cm−1.
Fig. 8
Infrared absorption spectra of Bi2O3-containing lithium phosphate glass before gamma irradiation

Inspection of the IR spectra of Bi2O3 containing samples indicates that introducing Bi2O3 up to 5 % shows no changes in the main IR spectral features observed from the base lithium phosphate glass. On reaching 7.5 % Bi2O3, three changes are observed: (1) A broad and medium band is highly identified extending from about 680 to 880 cm−1; (2) The prominent and strong peaks at about 850, 920 and 1090 cm−1 are observed to grow in intensity and combined as a very broad band; and (3) A separate small band is still identified at about 600 cm−1.

Section2.Heading: Effect of gamma irradiation on IR spectra
Section2.Para:
Figure 9 illustrates the IR spectra of the prepared glass samples after being gamma irradiated with a dose of 6 Mrad. Inspection of the IR curves reveals the following spectral variations:
(a)
The base lithium phosphate glass without Bi2O3 shows obvious changes; the first band near 500 cm−1 highly increases in intensity and becomes the highest band identified. The small peaks within the 550–700 cm−1 region have almost disappeared. The high band at about 1350 cm−1 highly decreases. The small peak at about 1650 cm−1 becomes prominent as a medium band.
(b)
The glasses containing progressive additional Bi2O3 content show different responses than the base glass. With increasing Bi2O3 up to 4 %, the intensities of all the main IR bands progressively decrease and the near-IR bands within the 3000–3700 cm−1 region reveal obvious increase with the final resolution of a high intense composite band with several component peaks at about 3100, 3390, and 3700 cm−1. The two final samples containing 5 and 7.5 % Bi2O3 exhibit very close response towards irradiation. The band at about 500 cm−1 is observed to be predominantly resolved while the other bands within the 950–1350 cm−1 region show the diminishing of the resolution and the band at about 1650 cm−1 is still present as a medium one.
(c)
It can be generally concluded that gamma irradiation causes an obvious decrease of the resolution together with quite splitting of the IR bands except of the two bands, the first at 500 cm−1 and the bands within the 3100–3750 cm−1 region in some samples.
Fig. 9
Infrared absorption spectra of Bi2O3-containing lithium phosphate glass after 6 MR gamma irradiation

Section2.Heading: Origin of ultraviolet and near visible absorption in undoped and Bi2O3-containing lithium phosphate glasses
Section2.Para: It has been suggested by several authors [13, 14] that the charge transfer UV bands usually observed in undoped commercial glasses originate from trace iron impurities even if present in the ppm level. Paul [15] and Parke and Webb [16] have observed a UV peak when traces of Bi3+ ions are added in borate and phosphate glasses and the transition of this peak was related to 1s0 3p1.

Duffy and Ingram [17, 18] and Duffy [19] have agreed to this assignment and have recognized and classified differently originated ultraviolet absorption in glasses. Some transition metal ions (e.g., Fe3+, Cr6+) in glass exhibit characteristic charge transfer ultraviolet absorption spectra even if present in the ppm level. Such metal ions owe their ultraviolet spectra to an electron transfer mechanism. But certain other metal ions including Ce3+, U4+, as well d10S2 (ions such as Pb2+ and Bi3+) absorb radiation through electronic transitions involving orbitals essentially of the metal ion only, and the name “Rydberg” has been suggested for such spectra to distinguish them from the common charge electron transfer spectra.

It can thus assumed that the ultraviolet and near-visible absorption bands observed in the studied undoped and Bi2O3-containing glasses that originate from both the sharing of trace iron impurities within the raw materials and also due to absorption from Bi3+ ions when Bi2O3 is added to the phosphate glass. This assumption was recently reached by ElBatal et al. on their optical studies on Bi2O3-containing silicate and borate glasses [5–7]. The attribution of the near visible band to be due to Bi3+ was assigned by Parke and Webb [16] to be 1s0 3p1 and Duffy and Ingram [17, 18] and Duffy [19] agreed to this assignment.

Concerning to the presence of bismuth color center in bismuth containing glasses, many ideas have been suggested on the formation of this optical color center and luminescence center and several proposals are introduced:
(a)
The presence of pentavalent bismuth ion (Bi5+) ions [20],
(b)
The presence of monovalent bismuth (Bi1+) [21],
(c)
The presence of Bi clusters or Bi colloids [22, 23].
However the final statement of such centers is still in debate.

Khonthon et al. [24] have investigated the color, spectral, and NIR luminescence properties of bismuth in borate and silicate glasses at different temperatures and also after carbon addition as a reducing medium. This study includes SEM and XPS measurements of various colored samples. Such authors [24] have suggested that there are few color centers and luminescent centers in the studied glasses. They have also suggested that the centers are likely to be caused through lower valence state species of Bi, such as Bi clusters (e.g., dimer, trimer, etc.) and Bi+.

It is of great importance to mention that our extended studies on various bismuth borate, bismuth silicate, and bismuth phosphate glasses [5–7] have indicated the preparation of homogeneously colored glasses melted under atmospheric condition. The samples exhibit characteristic UV-near visible bands due to trivalent bismuth (Bi3+) ions and the same optical bands have been identified in various publications [15–19, 24, 25].

Section2.Heading: Effect of gamma irradiation on UV-visible absorption spectra
Section2.Para: Damage defects generated by radiation in pure materials are accepted to originate at imperfections present before irradiation [10–12]. Glasses have normally short range order and do contain numerous defect sites such as vacancies, nonbridging oxygens, impurities, etc. The existence of such structural defects is assumed to occur in a solid because the free energy is minimized by admitting a certain amount of disorder in the structure [12].

To interpret the effect of successive gamma irradiation on the base lithium phosphate and the effect of increasing Bi2O3 contents, it must born in mind that there is a basic difference between silicate and phosphate glasses although the basic structural units in both glasses are tetrahedral groups. The pentavalent phosphorous atom is coordinated to three bridging oxygens and one non-bridging oxygen with a double bond in pure P2O5 glass, whereas the tetravalent silicon is coordinated to four nonbridging oxygens in SiO2 glass. Thus, the addition of alkali oxide to P2O5 creates double bridging oxygens that will presumably shared by the others. It is speculated that gamma irradiation will affect the base lithium phosphate glass itself with its intrinsic defects already present in it including the nonbridging oxygens and trace iron impurities within the glass matrix.

Early in 1966, Beekenkamp [26] proposed two models for irradiated color centers in alkali phosphate glasses. The first model for the 2.3 eV (≈540 nm) center comprised a hole trap in alkali phosphate glass, which consists of a positive hole trapped on a pair of nonbridging oxygens with the alkali having diffused away (color center I). The second model was proposed for the 2.9 eV (≈420 nm) hole trap center consisting of a hole trapped by an oxygen ion with the alkali covalently bonded to the oxygen (color center II). Beekenkamp [26] further assumed that the band at 6 eV (≈200 nm) is due to an oxygen vacancy in a PO4 tetrahedron which has trapped two electrons. Also, the induced band near 5.1 eV (≈245 nm) in alkali phosphate glass seems to arise from an electron in an antibonding orbital of a PO4 unit, which has no analog in silicate glass.

Arichidi et al. in 1996 [27] identified three induced defect centers in alkali phosphate glasses irradiated with x-rays. The first identified defect is assumed to be a hole trapped on a pair of non-bridging oxygens bonded to a single phosphrous atom. Additional centers are also identified, which are believed to be related to the peroxy linkage P–O–O–P and other related linkages.

In later studies, several authors [28–30] recognized many radiation induced defects in a series of undoped and TM-doped phosphate glasses, which are formed as negative electron centers in the ultraviolet region and positive hole centers in the visible region. Besides the radiation induced centers generated from host alkali phosphate glasses, it is assumed that the two iron states (Fe2+, Fe3+) present as impurities can be affected by irradiation. Fe2+ ions can be photo-oxidized to Fe3+ ions and Fe3+ ions can be photo-reduced to Fe2+ ions according to photochemical reactions through liberated electrons or positive holes during the irradiation process [27–30].

Recent studies [31–33] on various binary phosphate glasses and including the introduction of CeO, V2O5, or MoO3 as a dopant have reached to comparable results regarding the effect of irradiation and similar interpretations have been achieved.

Section2.Heading: Induced spectra
Section2.Para:
Inspection of the induced spectra of undoped and Bi2O3-containing samples before and after successive gamma irradiation shown in Figs. 1–7 indicates the following spectral data:
(a)
The glasses containing up to 4 % Bi2O3 show strong charge transfer UV spectra as observed with the base glass without Bi2O3 and the resolution of an extra visible band at 400–470 nm and a kink at about 700 nm. The observed shift to longer wavelength from 210 to 235 nm and the resolution of an extra strong band at 275 nm after gamma irradiation can be related to the conversion of some Fe2+ ions to Fe3+ by photochemical reaction through irradiation by capturing positive holes, and thus the UV spectra are revealing prominence in the same positions for the bands which are known for absorption of Fe3+ ions. The visible band and the kink at 400–470 and 700 nm, respectively, are correlated with Bi3+ ions. These visible bands are observed to be slightly decreased in intensity or remain unchanged with progressive irradiation. This behavior is correlated with the known ability of the heavy and large atomic number Bi3+ ions to shield irradiation. Several authors [6–9] have reached the same results and conclusions in different glasses containing Bi2O3.
(b)
The optical spectra of the two glasses containing 5 % Bi2O3 and 7.5 % Bi2O3 reveal strong connected UV-visible spectra consisting of two UV bands at 235 and 275 nm and are followed by two distinct visible peaks at 400 and 470 nm beside a curvature at about 700 nm. Gamma irradiation is observed to cause no visual changes on the observed absorption spectra. It is evident that the presence of the higher Bi2O3 contents (5 % and 7.5 %) causes obvious shielding behavior toward successive gamma irradiation, and thus preventing further changes in the spectral curves.
(c)
Figures 6 and 7 illustrate the induced spectra of the Bi2O3-containing glasses after irradiation with 3 and 6 Mrad, respectively. The overall net induced results indicate that gamma irradiation with 3 Mrad, produces an induced UV sharp band at 275 nm, which slightly decreases with the Bi2O3 content accompanied by a shift to 285 nm. A visible induced band at 430 nm is also resolved. With 6 Mrad, the induced spectra are observed to comprise from two bands in the UV region at about 220 and 275 nm and a distinct induced visible band at about 440 nm together with a small kink at about 700 which is sharply identified with higher Bi2O3 contents.

Section2.Heading: Interpretation of the infrared absorption spectra
Section2.Para:
The realization and interpretation of the IR spectra has been carried out taking into consideration the concept adopted by Tarte [34] and Condrate [35] about the free independent vibrations of different structural units in glasses irrespective of the presence of other structural groups. The same approach is successively applied by Dimitriev et al. [36] and ElBatal et al. [5–7, 30–33]. Such an empirical treatment is expected to provide significant information about the type of structural units present in the glass and their arrangements. The following assignments are introduced regarding the observed IR bands in the studied glasses taking into consideration previous interpretations by various authors on the IR spectra of phosphate glasses [30, 36–41]:
(a)
The IR band at about 475 cm−1 can be assigned to the bending vibrations of the O–P–O bond and (PO2) modes of (PO3) n chain groups.
(b)
The band in the range 600–650 cm−1 is related to the fundamental frequency of (PO4)3− groups or to the harmonics of P=O bending vibrations.
(c)
The medium peak at 790 cm−1 is attributed to the symmetric stretching vibrations (P–O–P) rings.
(d)
The strong band at about 920 cm−1 is related to different metaphosphate groups in the form of chain ring and terminal group and to the asymmetric stretching of (P–O–P).
(e)
The strong band at 1090 cm−1 is attributed to the asymmetric stretching of V as (P–O–P) modes linked with small metaphosphate rings.
(f)
The very strong band at about 1315 cm−1 can be assigned to the stretching vibrations that contain the doubly bonded oxygen, O=P–O.
(g)
The small peak at about 1640 cm−1 can be related to the P–O–H bridges.
(h)
The small peaks at about 2040, 2300, 2780, 2820, and 2910 cm−1 can be related to H2O molecules or OH groups.
(i)
The broad band centered at about 3440 cm−1 can be related to H2O or POH vibrations.

Regarding the changes observed upon the addition of increasing Bi2O3 contents, the IR spectra of Bi2O3-containing glasses can be realized and interpreted as follows:
(1)
The most fundamental effects of the introduction of Bi2O3 especially on reaching 7.5 % are the appearance of a strong broad band within the region 680–880 cm−1 and the growth of the bands at about 1090 and 1350 cm−1.
(2)
Inspite of extensive recent studies on Bi2O3 containing glasses [7, 42–49]; there is still controversy about the type of groupings of Bi–O units in various glass systems. Most of these studies agree that bismuth atoms could form BiO3 and BiO6 structural units appearing alone or together with varying ratios depending on the type and nature of the other glass constituents. These studies have agreed that the IR bands in the 400–600 cm−1 region are related to bending Bi–O–Bi vibrations (BiO6 or BiO3 group). Some authors have assumed that the band in the region 820–50 cm−1 is due to BiO3 groups while the band in the region 860–890 cm−1 is related to BiO6. Thus, the observed additional strong and broad band in the region 680–880 cm−1 can be correlated to the presence of Bi–O groupings. Further studies are still needed to clarify such various groupings and their vibrational positions in relation to their corresponding crystalline analogues.

The changes in the IR absorption spectra upon the addition of Bi2O3 to the lithium phosphate glass can also be interpreted in accordance with recent studies on related glasses [46] as follows:
(a)
The changes in the IR spectra are due to the formation of short chains of phosphate network, or a decrease in the average phosphate chain length [48].
(b)
It has already been reported that when modifier cations are added in phosphate glasses, polymerization takes place through the breaking of long chains in the glass network [37, 38, 49].
(c)
The formation of P–O–Bi bonds which replaces the P–O− bonds and leads to an increase in the amplitude of the bands in the region 850–1090 cm−1, which grow in intensity with the addition of Bi2O3.

Section2.Heading: Interpretation of the effect of gamma irradiation on IR absorption spectra
Section2.Para:
Previous recent studies on the effect of gamma irradiation on the IR spectra obtained from different types of glasses have reached to several important contributions which can be summarized as follows:
(a)
ElBatal and ElDin [50] claimed that successive gamma irradiation on borosilicate glasses progressively decreased the intensity of the IR absorption bands. They interpreted this result to be due to a weakness or disorder in glass network, which was originated from the rupture of some bonds including primarily nonbridging oxygens upon progressive gamma irradiation.
(b)
ElBatal et al. [51] have observed that gamma irradiation on heavy bismuth borate glasses causes some variations in their IR spectra especially for the IR bands due to water and BOH groups while the main bands due to various borate groups (BO3 and BO4 units) remain unaffected. The authors [48] have assumed that gamma irradiation is only effective in this glass on the IR bands of unconstitutional groups with weak bonds while the main glass forming units (BO3, BO4, and Bi–O units) are stable and shielded by the presence of heavy metal oxide (Bi2O3).
(c)
ElBatal et al. [52] have recently observed that gamma irradiation causes only a minor decrease of the intensities of the IR bands observed due to lithium borate glasses accompanied by the lost of their sharpness. They have correlated their results with the previous observations and suggestions of Primak [53], Hobbs et al. [54], and Piao et al. [55] who considered that irradiation can cause changes in the bond angles and/or bond lengths of the constitutional structural units. These authors [50–52] have introduced some proposed mechanisms for radiation induced defects generation.

Based on all previous assumptions, the changes in the IR absorption spectra of the studied glasses upon gamma irradiation can be correlated with the occurrence of some variations in the bond angles and/or bond lengths of P–O–P bridges together with the contribution of bismuth ions (Bi3+) on the shielding effect toward successive gamma irradiation as suggested by various authors [50–55]. The response of the band at 500 cm−1 and that in the near IR bands 3100–3750 cm−1 seems to be correlated with the weakness in bonding as suggested before [50].

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: Optical (UV-visible) absorption spectrum of undoped host lithium phosphate glass reveals strong UV absorption, which is related to the presence of unavoidable trace iron impurities within the raw materials used for its preparation. The addition of Bi2O3 in increasing amounts (up to 7.5 % Bi2O3) produces additional UV and near visible bands at about 400–700 nm and at 690–700 nm, which are attributed to the presence of Bi3+ ions. Gamma irradiation causes the resolution of induced UV-visible bands, which are correlated with the effect of irradiation on both the host phosphate glass and trace iron impurities together with Bi2O3 added. Experimental optical results indicate obvious shielding behavior toward successive gamma irradiation especially at high Bi2O3 contents. Infrared absorption spectra of the studied glasses show characteristic bands due to specific phosphate groups. The introduction of Bi2O3 shows additional IR absorption bands due to the sharing of BiO3 and BiO6 units. Gamma irradiation produces minor variations in the intensities of some IR bands, which are related to the effect of irradiation on the weakness or disorder in the network or changes in bond angles or bond lengths between the structural building units.
